And even in democratic countries, are we always just supposed to trust authority with this kind of power? Presumably the rich, who we all know aren't so ethical in positions of power. problem with the ethics debate is that it (ironically) ignores the actual issue with "mind reading" technology. using the cars as an example misses the point, because cars don't make it possible to jail someone for thought crimes. technologies cannot be divorced from the contexts in which they are created. they are not neutral things that cause harm if found in the "wrong hands".

but even going back to cars, there's a reason personal cars exist instead of a network of a robust public transport, just like there's a reason why the ancient greeks never invented railways despite knowing about steam power. because that's what the social environment dictated. what you are seeing here are the seeds of a particular set of technologies. it remains to be seen how they will develop.

Im sorry, I don’t normally say stuff like this but the camera work and overall production quality is on this is really the antithesis of what YouTube should be trying to do with these YouTube Originals. It feels like it exists in this uncanny valley between authentic user generated content and a polished original show you might see on another streaming service. It looks technical professional sure. But certain things... little too deliberate set design, overuse of camera motion, many unnecessary cuts, a simple interview shot with inconsistent and jarring camera angles, the yellow cast monochromatic color grading for no apparent reason... and that’s just the technical side. All of this makes the actual substance feel way more inauthentic than it should, like you had to shoot it a bunch of times over. Luckily Michael is a great personality and can still carry the show on his shoulders. But it would be so much better if you used the tools you had to focus on the story and not try to mimic all those other shows. Use the production value to enhance the kind of content Michael is best at instead of putting him into a format you think will sell.

I think the problem is not determining what parts of the brain are active in recognizing facial features, I think it's the reconstruction itself. they can't know exactly what he's thinking of and how it looks in his mind. because brains don't produce a clear image, but even if they did you'd have to test more than just what they are testing... additionally, I don't think brains are suited to remember still images, I think in terms of remembering a certain person like a celebrity, let's say, Jennifer Lawrence, we remember how she talks, how she smiles, her little awkward laugh, that time when she tripped over herself. We may not even fully visualize the person are talking about, well... at least I don't. it's an interesting subject, but do you see the person you're talking about in your brain? Because I can only see a very vague image and maybe imagine their voice, not a clear photograph. some details certainly escape my attention. but as a person who paints I know the more you linger on trying to remember someone's features - the more fleshed out they become. but we can't reproduce it perfectly in our minds, we need the physical world for that - and then we can see the wrinkles near the eyes, the eyebrow shape, etc...

Do you know how you hear your voice in your head? The mechanical part. The way your body allows you to hear your own voice?

Not many do. It's just something that's there and you never think of it, it just happens.

Here is how.

There is a part of your brain that's for language/speaking.

That part of your brain automatically tells your vocal cords to vibrate the word your thinking of saying.

Then when you push the air out of your lungs, air goes thru your vocal cords, and that's how we hear each other out loud.

When we don't push the air out, our vocal cords are vibrating against our bones in our throat and our inner ear pick up the sound from that vibration.

When you're dreaming that your talking, not talking out loud in your bed, but to somebody in your dream, that part of your brain does not know that you're dreaming,

It just knows you want to talk.

So, it vibrates your vocal cords and when you're having a conversation with somebody in your dream....

guess what?

Your vocal cords are vibrating both parts of the conversation.

It is all you.

If you get a real sensitive microphone place it in the area of the vocal cords and when a person is talking in a dream not out loud, you would be able to hear them.

So when you sitting and thinking of what to say…..

You're sitting and thinking,,,

Your thinking…..

You're thoughts,,,,

You hear it right?

Your hear all of it.

It's all the same.


Everything you think of, thoughts, think, whatever you hear it in your head, subconsciously thinking, it is words you hear, which means your vocal cords are vibrating your thoughts.

Your brain doesn't hear,

your ears do.

Now, doesn't that just blow your mind ???

No one really thinks why that happens and we just always assumed that it was just separate.

Thinking. your thoughts, your inner voice always thought of it being separate.

It's just one of those things we don't even think about .

Nobody really knows about this,

Now that you're aware of it, you'll be paying more attention to your thinking, your thoughts, your inner voice.

And…...

I just taught you away to listen to your subconscious it's also there. I was forced to learn this.

It freaked me out at first.



You will forget how it was, how it was all separate..

Ok I'm paraphrasing, but seriously, "It's already happening" and "we wear clothes so..." aren't really serious stances. There's something to be said for restraint, I fundamentally disagree with the idea that the celebrated scientists in all their proud glory can't restrain themselves from doing work like this with very specific and limited utility. And if not at least they could refuse military RnD contracts. But no, they can't apparently and so we have ICBMs and fission/fusion weaponry with very specific and limited utility in our society.

To claim that "because sweater!" we aren't "wild", is no different than to claim that fungus farming termites that construct a mound aren't "wild". Rather our ability to create a varied technology based on our cultures' varied values/interests/inertias is itself a part of our nature and thus "natural", the urge to alienate people from nature is a bogus kind of essentialism that seems to lead to a great deal of confusion and misery about our place in the ecology of this planet. We aren't special from the perspective of a termite and a termite is not currently causing a mass extinction with it's arrogance.

As a little bonus, there's a bit he glossed over about the process of machine learning that makes this sort of technology more real, both in the sense of how very possible it is, and what its limitations are.

Generally speaking, any machine learning technique you apply is an attempt to map a set of inputs to a set of outputs, y=f(x), just like any mathematical function you'd find in math; instead of finding x or y, you're trying to figure out f. Most machine learning functions do this by having a whole bunch of inputs with their correct outputs (referred to as a dataset), and then having a computer run the machine learning algorithm on the data to "discover" f.

Getting more technical: Because of the nature of what they're doing in this episode, you can reverse engineer what their machine learning algorithm must have looked like. Since they're dealing with mapping fMRI to facial imagery, you can pretty much guarantee they're using a Deep Convolutional Neural Network. This type of machine learning model is also suggested by the fact that they needed to send Michael away "process" the images (or in other words, train their network on the 400-some-odd random "non-celebrity" fMRI to face pairs, and then feed in the 10 fMRI scans that should map to celebrities to see how it holds up in testing). And, judging by the fidelity of the output images, their working with a model that's been pretrained for facial image generation. It suggests that they might have taken the generative half of a trained Generative Adversarial Network and appended it to a Convolutional Neural Net that maps fMRI down to something like a 128-dimensional vector for the generative half to decode back into a face.

What does that say to me? It says that this is impressive, carefully considered work, but that it probably needs more time to refine, and probably needs more training instances to build confidence in their model (like they say in the episode, it could be michael's imperfect memory, or it could be the machine). I'd be interested to see if their results improve when training on data from multiple people's fMRI sessions together, in part because it'd mean a more robust training dataset, but honestly more because having a model like this improve its performance under those conditions would heavily suggest that brain functioning between individuals is largely consistent, if not nearly identical.

The “progress is inevitable” conclusions drawn at the end here remind me of Harris’s deterministic apologetics, but on a higher order of magnitude. Do we as a species really have much control over the emergence of these technologies, and by extension, are we collectively powerless to prevent ceding our heretofore sacrosanct rights & privileges to their exponentially expanding domain?

Is there a name for the ethical argument that “the locus of moral value is not in the technology, but in the user”? Let’s call it Material Amoralism. It seems to me to be a somewhat excessively utilized axiom, to which there may be a multitude of exceptions... at least by degrees. The primary variables upon which the applicability of this assertion depends are; the nature of the function of the technology, the fixedness of the function in the thing & the extent to which this function may potentially insulate or abrogate the rights & wellbeing of the human population. Maybe I’ll go do some reading on this topic before I run my mouth too much more...

VSauce, A question was presented to me and my crew involving orbital motions between planetary objects and their satellites in reference to revolution times. We are coming to a split decision as to whether who is "correct" and are hoping that you may be able to apply a solid scientific standard to identify which is fact; or who is "more" correct.


The question presented was, "Given our earth, and referencing a satellite locked into a geostationary orbit, how long does it take for the satellite to complete one revolution around the earth?"


We have come to two points of conclusion:


1. That a satellite is in an orbit around the earth, regardless of whether it is a geostationary or not. It develops that orbit by creating a motion path that "encircles" the earth and therefore follows the rules for a geosynchronous orbit time which equates to one sidereal day(approx 23hr 56min 4sec) to complete a revolution around the earth. This argument is further supported by thinking of the satellite orbit based on the center mass point of the earth being a "single point" in space as the reference and that the satellite orbits that center mass point(point in space not in motion).
This argument is countered with the logic that in order for the geostationary satellite to complete a revolution, its "stationary" position would have to be forgone and either the satellite itself must accelerate or decelerate in relation to the referenced point(earth) in order to complete its revolution; or vice-versa(earth accelerates/decelerates its rotation).
2. Since we are using the earth as the reference point, that the "Geostationary" orbit locks the "0 degree" reference point with the satellite to the ground point and degree reference on earth and as such, a geostationary satellite cannot complete one revolution around earth.
This argument is countered changing the point of view of the observer. If an observer is external to both the earth and it's geostationary satellite, it appears that the satellite will rotate around the earth(not accounting the earth's rotation)


Please help, does a geostationary satellite complete a revolution around the earth? If so, how often?


In the case that you make a video and If you can prove that a geostationary satellite does not make a revolution around the Earth, please say in your video, "Curtis Longoria, you owe 1st Squad Pizza" at some point towards the end.

Perhaps they might be able to get better face drawing accuracy if the ML algorithms were paired with sliding window correlation, or some other filter temporally elastic filter that can pick up the representational correlates of face structure over time [3].

3. Nakai, T., Bagarinao, E., Matsuo, K., Ohgami, Y., & Kato, C. (2006). Dynamic monitoring of brain activation under visual stimulation using fMRI—the advantage of real-time fMRI with sliding window GLM analysis. Journal of neuroscience methods, 157(1), 158-167.

The first scientist to photograph dreams-in Kyoto university-that is so mindblowing. What we saw in those blurred images was the very beginning of photographing and even filming live dreams from a human subconscious. And before the images, the machine learning programme accurately predicted that the person was dreaming about 'characters;. If the person had been shown say a million images, rather than a thousand, the results would have been even more accurate, because the more training the better machine learning A.I works. In order to get accurate photographs from dreams e.g. the people in our dreams, it would take an unbelievable amount of time with a person with an eeg on their head looking at words and images and also seeing how their emotions appear on eeg,  for weeks or months. a similar process to how self drive car machine learning works.

On the contrary, I think that ethics should be the once deciding what technology we need and what technology we can and should do without. An Ethics that thinks it's good just because it allows whatever technology to be developed will end up defeating its own purpose. Technology's benefits not always depend on who uses it. Some technology is objectively bad. Think of biological weapons or nuclear weapons.
Also, just because we invented cars without having an ethical discussion about whether we should use them or not doesn't mean that that's how the natural process of development should go or goes. A lot of societal factors were involved in order for cars to be developed. They came at a time of capitalism, industrialization, greed, etc. We can't ignore that these factors contributed to the invention of cars, among many other machines. Some of these factors might not have been the ideal grounds to decide whether we should invent something or not. That's why ethical discussions should happen first. And if ethical discussions resolve that we're better off without a particular technology, so be it.
